ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I am not sure how well known this course is. I am positive more students would have taken this course if it was advertised/described differently. This is a similar to a clinic course focused on federal lands and policy. It goes over US policy/government structure.

This class provided an extremely interesting perspective on working on policy issues, especially in Washington DC. The coursework mixed readings on the structure and function of various policy entities in the federal government with more anecdotal and experiential lessons about how to advance your policy agenda in the face of non-institutional obstacles. I really appreciated how much emphasis was placed on working with people and developing relationships to achieve policy goals. Overall I think this class is immensely useful for anyone interested in working in Washington or for the federal government--extremely useful for FES students!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Working with clients was great--very challenging and it allowed us to get a sense of what a career in advocacy or policy may entail. I especially enjoyed how hands-on this course was. We didn't focus much on theory, and instead looked at case studies and presentations from speakers to articulate and discuss aspects of the policy process. I think the coursework in this class is probably some of the most useful for students (like myself) who are interested in working in government/policy.

Client project and D.C. networking trip. While the projects got off to a late start, it was incredibly valuable to work on a real project for a client and to understand how this project fit into their broader work.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: This course was poorly organized. Deadlines and deliverables were not clear, which is frustrating when other courses follow their syllabus. I think this course used to have multiple client projects, mock testimonials etc. This did not happen this semester. I think this would have been more useful than one project for the entire semester - which someone could get from a clinic course.

It was hard to know when deadlines were, and communication was slow over email. This lead to unnecessary stress and some disorganization with my client interactions which could have reflected poorly on my work.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about the policy process in Washington and in federal agencies in a manner that wasn't solely focused on theory or the architecture of the federal government. I wanted a course that would provide me with experience, understanding, and professional skills to help me build a career in federal policy. This class was a great complement to other clinical/practicum courses like EPC, which focuses more on advocacy work. I feel like this course prepared me extremely well for a career in the federal government.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work in this course was great, mostly because my partner was extremely helpful, responsive, and engaged. I really enjoyed working with my project partner to create a policy document and deliverable for our client.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This course is probably most interesting to those interested in US policy/government, specifically the Interior Department.

If your are interested in working in government, especially in agencies/the White House/Capitol Hill in Washington DC, definitely take this course. Jim has immense experience and so many stories that are applicable to the issues we will face in our careers. I definitely recommend this class to other students at FES.
